participants.participant: Sascha Bibert, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations
Johannes Teyssen, Chairman, Management Board and Chief Executive Officer

plist.p: Dear ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the conference call of E.ON. At our customers' request, this conference will be recorded. As a reminder, all participants will be in a listen-only mode. After the presentation, there will be an opportunity to ask questions.
May I now hand you over to Mr. Sascha Bibert, who will lead you through this conference.

Thank you very much and good afternoon everyone. Welcome to the E.ON Conference Call and the 2010 Results. Johannes Teyssen, our CEO will summarize the key financials, comment on the significant progress we made with respect to our portfolio and balance sheet management. Update you on the European generation environment and the situation of our global gas business. Briefly discuss our activities outside Europe and finally comment on our performance initiatives. Thereafter, Marcus Schenck, our CFO will go into the details of the 2010 financials as well as the outlook for the coming years.
With that, I give the floor to Johannes.

Good afternoon, everyone. Before Marcus take the usual details into our 2010 financials and the outlook for the coming year. Let me share with you my prospective on the E.ON conference today. I have been appointed as CEO, roughly 12 months ago. The times and the general economy was just recovering from very severe crisis. The negative impact on the energy industry came with certain time lack that was not less pronounced.

Equally, the recovery within the sector will take time especially since an increase in demand alone will not be adequate enough. We at E.ON are convinced that our sector is undergoing a radical change, a change which requires new answers and new approaches, which then and only then continue to offer plenty of opportunities in the coming years.

The changes driven not only by the general economic development which among others will lead to a different balance between developed and developing regions, but it's equally due to a changing political and regulatory environment. The long-term drivers of growth however are obvious. Climate and environmental protection limited both our fuel resources and a growing energy consumption worldwide.

That said; capturing the value arising from those drivers will require far more than successfully reaping the benefits from eventually rising prices and spreads. This is why we developed a new strategy, a strategy to be executed by a new and very determined team, which reaches far beyond the bottom.

A new strategy based on a completely revised organizational setup, which will significantly increase the activity and transparency of our group. In the nutshell, our game plan is based upon first, it could be positioning on the value change; second, a clear view on the prospects of individual geographic regions and their potentials; thirdly, the performance and excellent culture as a primary driver of activity shaping our own future; and forth and lastly, an investment philosophy, which recognizes that the capital scales and valuable resource. The transformation that we have in front of us is not without risk if you turn over. However, for the benefit of our shareholders, our customers and employees, we're determined to make that a traceable and tangible success.

We closed the year 2010 successfully broadly inline with expectations. 2011, from today's standpoint, mark the bottom in our earnings development. The following years thereafter are expected to show higher profits year-by-year. Based on the excellent position of our conventional generation fleet, our growing investments in renewable generation, E&P in Russia, will increasingly shape our bottom line. The potential recovery of prices and spreads is down an additional upside optionality on top for our current communication expense.

The portfolio management activity that will support our transformation, will lead to a loss of earnings in the near term. However with the recent divestments, selectively pursued to maximize value, we have regained our financial flexibility and further divestment proceeds will be reinvested into E.ON's future. We will not put assets into the ground if they are not needed.
However, if we see plenty of opportunities and needs for our skills and competencies, and have therefore no reason to change our communication and targets with respect to our overall CapEx program.

After this general scene setting, let me now quickly comment on our current financial situation. E.ON's operating 2010 results are in line with the outlook the we have given throughout the year. Despite the €800 million negative impact from earlier disposals, adjusted EBITDA ended up 3% higher than the prior year, adjusted EBIT rose 2%.

On a like-for-like basis, excluding those disposals, EBIT of the ongoing operations would have improved by more than 10%. For me, this demonstrates the strength of our underlying operations. I would also like to point out the development in our new markets, adjusted for one effects – one-off effects. An example, the 2009 contract renegotiation in Italy and profits comp out to A2A, the EBIT in the new markets up over 50% year-on-year.

Adjusted net income is 4% lower than the prior year. This is driven by higher minority interests and a one-off item leading to higher interest expense. As announced at the Capital Market Day, we propose to pay out a dividend of €1.50 per share. This corresponds to a payout of 59% of adjusted net income is therefore within the range we've always announced.

I'm also very pleased with the continued positive development of the operating cash flow, up €2 billion to €10.6 billion. Thanks to these strong operating cash flow as well as disposal proceeds. We reduced the debt factor to a very satisfactory level of 2.8 times including disposal signed within 2011, the debt factor at pro forma level would even further go down to 2.5 times.

Let me remind you in this respect that the EBIT – that the E.ON's debt factor is based upon economic net debt. The pure net financial liabilities amount only just over half of the total economic debts with the remainder mainly the asset retirement obligations being of a very, very long-term nature. This should underline the point I made earlier. Our balance sheet is in order. The absolute amount of debt has seen its peak last year and we can now consciously develop the group forward in line with our strategy.

This brings me to the 2011 outlook. We expect adjusted EBITDA to come out between €11.2 billion at €11.9 billion, 10% to 15% lower than in 2010. There are some large negative developments affecting the earnings this year. The introduction of the nuclear tax in Germany, negative margins in gas supply and sales, the decline of power prices and spreads as well as the absence of positive one-off effects in our German regulated activities.

On the positive side however, we are well on track to PerformtoWin program, also the investments in Russia in renewable generation and in E&P are also increasingly paying off. So 2011 would not be an easy year. The environment is challenging and we are going through a transformation phase to make E.ON a better company and a more attractive investment in the medium-term. I have however, no doubt that we will be successful. This is also why we set a minimum dividend of €130 per share for 2011 and 2012, which was already recognized in the markets. Beyond this, we have no reason to change our 2013 targets of achieving an adjusted EBITDA of more than €13 billion before portfolio changes.

Let me turn to chart two, based on our strengths and competencies, we have set out our new strategy and discussed it with you on November, 10. The strategy is based on four key pillars. In Europe, we will move away from being integrated across the entire value chain towards a more focused portfolio centered on competitive businesses.
Secondly, we will develop the group from a Eurocentric position to expand selectively outside Europe.

Third, individual efficiency programs need to be transformed into a sustainable performance culture. And fourth, change from capital-intensive business models, the solutions that create value based on leveraging our competencies not solely our capital. We are now focused on delivering on this strategy. Within a few months, we have already made tangible progress that we had discussed along lines of these four strategic pillars.

Okay, change to chart number three, last week, we reached an agreement to sell the business of Central Networks in England to PPL for an enterprise value of £4.0 billion including the transfer of £0.2 billion of pension provisions. Central Networks is still a well performing distribution business. As part of our strategic review, we have also sell fiber, so that we are the best owner, whether we have enough opportunities to create additional value.

Let me point out three key areas in this respect; first, financial flexibility, the freedom to invest and optimal cost of capital. The last distribution price review requires Central Networks to invest £2.3 billion over the next five years, making the business overall free cash flow negative in all medium-term years.

We see however capital allocation as a key value driver. This business leaves no room to maneuver. No opportunity to choose the best projects based upon the respective risk-return profile. A few of the investments are mandatory.
Second, the opportunity to outperform and to keep an attractive corresponding margin is limited. We do not have the full opportunity to make the best use of our skills and assets.
Third, value creation within the group is partially dependent on leveraging synergies, synergies across regions or functions; this is not possible in this case due to strict .

Overall, this transaction has been executed at excellent conditions. At outstanding multiples, at the right point, in time and supports us in swiftly executing our strategy. Following the sale of Central Networks, we nevertheless remain an important player in the UK market. With an installed power production capacity of roughly 10,000 megawatts and retail activities with almost 8 million in power and gas clients. Our activities in the UK continue to be a very influential part of the overall E.ON Group.

Turning to chart number four, with our focused European position, we target to free up around €15 billion of capital by the end of 2013. More than half of the disposal proceeds will be used to reduce debt. The remainder of it will be redeployed into more value creating activities mainly in renewable generation and outside Europe. In only four months, since our Capital Market Day, we have achieved close to €9 billion of disposal proceeds, €4.9 billion Central Networks, €3.4 billion our state gas firm, €0.3 billion for the disposal of our utility distribution network. And another €0.2 billion for a number of smaller transactions. On a like-for-like basis, the transactions achieved so far would reduce 2010 adjusted EBITDA by roughly €700 million and adjusted net income by a good €100 million. The corresponding debt factor would be 0.3 times lower.

Let me now turning to chart number five show a view of two key operational topics for the EU. First comment on the European generation environment; second update you on the status quo of our gas business, especially the long-term contract renegotiations. And a reduction in demand caused by economic slowdown and new productivities initiated before the crisis, as well as new renewables have lead to a quite substantial oversupply in many European markets.

Various political decisions and plans sometimes in contradiction to developments in other parts of the world have further influenced the energy system and increased the challenges for the European generators. Here, I'm thinking about the sustained increase in intermittent renewable generation and as well as uncertainty around the future carbon market.

Combined those developments have not only depressed spreads, but they also called for very different skills and assets in order to outperform peers and to generate value going forward. However, next the obvious state, there is always light. The market situation may not be as bleak as some suggest. Many commercial plants are currently only covering their fixed cost by selling the CO2 certificates that have been allocated for free. This will not be possible in – any more after 2013, when all CO2 certificates will be optioned. As a consequence, we believe the closures of conventional capacity might well come earlier and be larger than one might anticipate.

They will come earlier, because plants subject to the LCPD might well close ahead of 2015 deadline and they will be larger, because some plants not subject to LCPD will become uneconomic as of 2013. What I outlined, is illustrated our graph, which sums up non-retirements of conventional capacity until 2015. Mainly due to LCPD plus the conventional capacity, which will pass the specific age until 2015, which is 45 years for coal and lignite and 32 years for CCGTs and 50 years for other gas plants.

We at E.ON are constantly assessing the economics of our own plants. The decision to open or close a plant is not taken top down but bottom-up in a very granular fashion. Looking at the risk return profile of old plants in the portfolio context, ranking them within the OP merit order. Let me be clear here. We are not waiting for the market to rescue anything. We have to take the market and act accordingly. We are absolutely convinced that especially in this environment, skills and assets are absolutely crucial to perform. Let me give you a few examples on that, that the value shift from the special energy markets, which is towards the reserve and balancing markets. To capture this value, you need a very flexible fossil generation asset, coupled with fast and efficient processes between the assets and the kind of dispatch and optimization function.

Operational excellence either via cost leadership, in our land for thermal plant or we're ensuring a high availability of outright assets, decisive competencies to operate in this environment. Our generation fleet as well our organizational setup, which involves a superior trading organization with seven days, 24 hours presence to capture value across the entire optimization period make me very confident that E.ON will operate successfully in the years to come.

Now a few comments combined with chart number six, on our gas business. Overall, our gas operations developed favorably in 2010. Marcus will take you through the effects in a minute. In spite of growing earnings in our upstream division, 2011 however, might experience a significant impact from the negative gas or Spread power wholesale business. In effect, we have already seen in the fourth quarter of the preceding year.

With respect to the electricity long-term contracts, the new round of renegotiations that have been triggered off as October are well progressing. But we have not yet reached a conclusion with the key counter parties. If necessary, we will trigger arbitration as soon as possible in line with our contractual rights. However, nothing forbids the parties to then continue their discussions at parallel with arbitration, quite the contrary. We remain confident that commercial discussions with the producers will eventually yield positive results.

I would like to emphasize once again that the negative margins that we are currently making in supply and sales are predominantly the result of a pure timing effect. The price we process allows both parties to adjust the price of the LTCs to changes in market circumstances. The basic principle is that the buyer must be able to market the natural gas economically. Accordingly, the price review mechanism ensures that the price risk rests with the producer making it profitable for the buyer to take the volume risk. Once the price review process is completed, the newly agreed price formula will be applied with respect to all the gas taken since the start of renegotiations. Due to the retroactive effect the price adjustments, the main risk of the importer is the temporary negative margin for the period in between price of use.

Nevertheless it remains very difficult to reliably estimate the timing and final outcome of the renegotiations. The ongoing discussions are very serious for those sites. Still I continue to expect that those contractual relationships, which have formed the backbone of many years of successful partnerships with mutual interest involved, will support an acceptable solution for all.
In terms of guidance, we expect global gas to achieve an adjusted EBITDA of between €700 million, €1.2 billion in 2011, down from €2 billion last year.

Our E&P business will continue to show good earnings momentum, as we will benefit from the start of production of in the second half of the year. However this will be partially offset by regulatory pressure on the earnings of Open Grid Europe, formerly E.ON Gas Transport.

All in all, the main reason for the decline of earnings is the move of supply and sales from a small profit in 2010 to a substantial loss this year. Depending on the further progress of the current renegotiations, a loss of around €1 billion may be realized in 2011 and is including in our forecast and outlook.

For 2013, the guidance provided at the Capital Market Day remains unchanged. Strong progress in E&P, some regulatory pressure continuing on Open Grid Europe and a return of supply and sales to a normalized level of earnings. This return to a normal level of earnings would be the result of such renegotiations and does not assume a recapping of gas or oil prices nor does it include any compensation for past losses.

The second pillar of strategy looked on chart seven, is our expansion outside Europe. In this respect, I would like to discuss developments in Russia and our preparation for entry into two additional markets. Russia had delivered a strong result in 2010 and I expect this development to continue.
Since the 1 January 2011, the Russian market has been fully liberalized. This is excludes the retail markets, which will remain regulated and which represents about 20% of the national demand.

Last year, the Russian government also finalized the framework for capacity payments. For all advance, the capacity fees cover the fixed cost, significant improvement in the prior situation for efficient capacities. But for the balance built since 2007, the capacity fees do not only cover the fixed cost, but also the capital costs including an adequate and fair return on investment. The capacity framework together with the free energy market is really a system, which is supportive for investments. There were some more recent statements from the government that caused concerns in the market, but in our view, they neither changed the big picture nor our financial projections. More important is that we remained at the forefront in terms of new build. We have already spent more than 50% of the EMR €2.3 billion for investments and we acquired a majority in OGK-4 in 2007.

In November last year, we commissioned the 400 MW Shaturskaya CCGT, and this year we'll start up the 800 MW CCGT and so both as well as a 400 MW at . As a result, we expect a further strong increase of adjusted EBITDA this year, from a little shy of €400 million in 2010 to between €500 million and €700 million next year – this year. We also remain confident of achieving between €800 million and €1 billion of adjusted EBITDA in 2013. So, all in all another example of value crystallization within our group.

Since our Capital Market Day, we have not stood still on our strategic goal to enter two new markets outside Europe, in addition to the existing operations in Russia and our new build in North America. As a reminder, our strategy for entry into such two new markets rests on the following guidelines.

First, we will focus on conventional renewed power generation. Second, we do not simply want to bring capital on the table; instead we want to combine our expertise with the know how of local partners. Third, we only prefer to take commodity exposure if there is a way to manage it. This is seldom the case in emerging markets and therefore we will need to limit commodity exposure in our new ventures outside Europe. And last but not least, any new activities based upon a very disciplined investment approach with adequate hurdles to ensure on appropriate return on capital.

Meanwhile a highly capable team sourced from various E.ON units is intensively working within this business and reports to Marcus. It has already carried out a pre-selection among a very large number of potential markets and shortlisted a handful of markets for further analysis.

In addition, the team is looking at how local needs can be met by E.ON's capabilities. To conclude, entering into two new markets outside Europe will represent a commitment for many years. And this commitment will all time require investments of several billions. These aren't the kind of decisions to take lightly; we are thus giving ourselves all the time necessary to carry out a profound analysis before committing any capital and communicating it.

Turning to the performance on chart eight, constant attention to improving operational performance is the third pillar of our new strategy. We are determined to establish a new performance culture; however, we first want to deliver on our previous commitments. This year we'll see the completion of PerformtoWin, a plant launched in 2008 to improve adjusted EBITDA by €1.5 billion until the end of this year.

The initiatives taken in 2009 and 2010 have already improved adjusted EBITDA by €1.1 billion on a recurrent basis. We are therefore fully on track to deliver €1.5 billion of performance improvements in 2011. And the majority of the improvements will come from projects to optimize sales processes and margins such as in the UK, efforts to reduce service and overhead costs, and better commercialization of storage and transmission capacities in the gas business. As part of our new strategy, we want to move away from single programs such as PerformtoWin. Instead we want to foster a performance culture across the whole group that will continuously generate performance improvements.

As I said in my introductory remark, we recognize performance improvements and efficiency enhancement as well as the keys to lead us to drive the bottom line. Independent of where the power price or the gas margin stands. And the first step, we have put in place a new organization, a leaner organization geared towards more efficiency, transparency, and control. Along with the new organization, we are changing the way our businesses are steered. The Sierra will be based on centrally monitored KPIs to reflect the main drivers of long-term value creation. The KPIs that would be used to steer each business have been defined and targets that has to be made against those are signed accordingly. Among others, this will significantly enhance the internal discussions moving away from debating the finances of individual legal entities towards focusing on operations.

We have communicated that we target another €600 million sustainable efficiency improvements on top of PerformtoWin by the end of 2013. Within this – about one third will come from procurement optimization.

Let me now conclude my opening remarks for today. Since we presented our new strategy about four months ago, we have already made some tangible progress. First, we executed major disposals at very attractive conditions, this addresses a debt leverage and we can now fully focus on profitable gross.

Second, we do not want to rely on the support from rising markets and are determined to control our own future. This is why we need to make a performance culture an intricate part of E.ON's DNA. The developments in 2010 and the outlook for the coming years make me very hopeful that we are on the right track. And third and finally, 2011 will obviously be a challenging financial year. While that it does not come as a surprise to us or you, and accordingly our conviction and optimism for the future year has not changed. This is why we reiterate the dividend of 150 per year for 2010 and have set and are committed to a minimum dividend of 130 for 2011 and 2012.
Marcus, now over to you and the last year.

Yeah. The investors, the analysts, Johannes already summarized the key numbers in his part. So let me go straight to the reconciliation of adjusted EBIT at group level on chart 11. The retail business in the UK is up by €0.3 billion, this is largely driven by higher volumes and improved margins as we explained throughout the last year. As expected, the very strong performance of the first half and especially Q1 lost a little bit pace during the third quarter and weakened in Q4. What remains though is still in a very nice positive sales cycle compared to 2009.

In our German DSO business, we've see €0.5 billion improvement over last year, of which €0.2 billion have a one-off character. We – here we recovered costs that we incurred in 2009. Based on our hedging strategy, we realized higher wholesale prices for 2010. As you know, this was probably peak year when you look two years back and two years forward. Hence, we see a better asset optimization result in energy trading related to our power portfolio.

As mentioned by Johannes earlier, we continue to implement PerformtoWin, the program added €500 million as an improvement in 2010 with highlighting clearly are the – is the earnings momentum in Russia, will be more than tripled our EBIT. As negatives I'd like to highlight in particular, the impact from disposals. We lost €800 million due to disposals made last year. We have to sell our German – we had to sell some German power capacity, our high voltage grid, as a consequence of our EU commitments and furthermore, we disposed off Thüga.

Please also note once again that E.ON U.S. Midwest, which we used to own until mid of last year recorded as discontinued operations in both the 2009 and 2010 numbers. One remark to the underlying economic performance, if you adjust 2009 for the EBIT contribution from those assets that we sold, the 2010 EBIT was actually up 11.4%. In 2009, we had a known – we have the known one-off effect of €200 million in Italy from the renegotiation of unfavorable power contracts.

And also in the last quarter of 2010, we have an addition of €0.1 billion nuclear decommissioning provision in Sweden and then finally in our gas transport business compared to 2009, we lost €200 million.

So much for the overall overview, now let me go straight into the segments over to page 13 starting with Central Europe. Overall, the 2010 financials were impacted in this market unit by lost deconsolidation effects. Transfer prices not reflective of the highest toll fair prices and one-off in the regulated business. As a result, EBIT was down 2%, here are the key reasons why Central Europe West dropped by €572 million. The deconsolidation of power plants in Germany had already heavily effected the first nine months. For the full-year, the effect now amounts to €390 million. The drop by €147 million in the nuclear fleet is caused by a mix of higher maintenance costs, higher expenses for revisions slightly increased depreciation and a reduced equity result. In France, the 2009 figures included the positive one-off effect from a provision release, which was not repeated in 2010. That was one of €90 million. Newly commissioned power plants with an attributable capacity of 1.2 gigawatts added around on €100 million.

Let me make one remark to generation business of Central Europe. The high average achieved price €68 per megawatt hour in the outright portfolio in 2010 does sit in the trading division. Central Europe has transferred its 2010 generation volume to energy trading in 2007 at the then prevailing 2010 forwards. EBIT then hedged a lot of the 2010 outright volume during the course of 2008, at obviously much higher prices. This already gives you an indication of why we will see the opposite effect in 2011. I'll come back to this when presenting the outlook for 2011.

Central Europe West regulated is up strongly by 21%. Higher distribution network revenues in both power and gas are the main driver. Also we see in 2010 delayed passing on of higher transmission grid costs, around €200 million. This is clearly a one-time effect. On the negative side, we recorded the deconciliation of transpower and then over to Central Europe East, that improves mainly because in a number of markets in particularly, Hungary and Romania, we see the recovery from the crisis. In addition, we do have some minor positive translation effects.

Let's move over to Pan-European Gas. As expected, earnings from the fourth quarter could not continue the strong momentum of the first nine months, which were up 19%. Given the known situation in our gas wholesale business, the fourth quarter showed negative earnings. Nevertheless, for the full year like-for-like earnings were basically flat year-on-year. Keep in mind that you got the consolidation.

The non-regulated business is up €216 million, primarily due to our E&P position. In upstream, we recorded €102 million positive price effects. Volume effects, which are a minus €48 million at the nine-month stage just neutral for the full year. The Russian gas field Yushno Russkoje contributed €78 million compared to last year. And in total we see a €400 million EBITS in our E&P business.

Supply and sales in absolute terms is still positive for the full year. Here the combined price and volume effect is plus €85 million. This includes the relief of an €80 million provision, which was booked in Q4 2009 and could be released in the first half of 2010. The key negative driver in supply and sales is the price effect i.e. the gas oil spreads. As a consequence, we left €420 million in the fourth quarter.

Starts are stable with the contribution, as we've communicated to you slightly north of €0.4 billion. The regulated business is down by slightly more than €200 million, mainly driven by the German gas transportation grid.

In the UK, we booked an increase in adjusted EBITS to €0.9 billion. As expected, we saw a further slowdown of the positive earnings momentum during the first two quarters of 2010 due to a very strong Q4 of 2009. EBIT is still up 37% year-on-year, but remember the corresponding growth rate was 180% up at the half-year results.

Regulated, next to currency translation, the regulatory price increase drove earnings at Central Networks. And then non-regulated in our part is up 71%. However, in the second-half of 2010, the non-regulated business added only €50 million on top of the roughly €500 million at half year.

Let me now move over to Nordic. In terms of operating performance, Nordic had a good 2011. The slightly reduced EBIT growth has to be seen in light of the fact that it includes a one-off increase of the nuclear decommissioning provisions of €120 million, which was booked in Q4 compared to 2009. EBIT is also benefiting from currency translation effects. Non-regulated earnings are down roughly €50 million.

We generated 5.3 terawatt hours more than in 2010 than in 2009. Main driver behind this improvement was nuclear power generation with an increase of 3.6 terawatt hours. Also our CHP and contributed to the increase with 1.5 terawatt hours. The higher nuclear volumes generated €100 million of additional earnings. This is partially offset by volume induced higher taxes for our nuclear generation. The hydro generation benefited from higher transfer prices. These positives were compensated by the increase in nuclear provisions. The regulated business was up €73 million, mainly based on higher network charges and high volumes resulting from the colder weather. Don't forget, Nordic heating is primarily a power market.

Adjusted EBITs of energy trading on page 17 is up 26% to €1.2 billion. As I explained in the context of Central Europe, the main driver for the absolute high profit number is the timing of the transfer of generation volume from our power generation businesses to energy trading.

Optimization is up almost €500 million, as you know certain gas procurement contracts originally transferred to E.ON from the UK are being optimized by energy trading. We added €76 million compared to 2009 on these assets. For those of you who are very detailed analysis, Q4 of 2009, had an especially strong result from that optimization. This was why the nine-month result for 2010 showed a higher improvement over 2009, then is the case for the full-year numbers. As expected, the core portfolio more than recovered from a slight dip in the third quarter to deliver an improvement of €178 million.

And then finally the power portfolio benefited from higher prices. Prop trading lost slightly north of €100 million in 2010. The trend of the first nine months continued in Q4. However, for the first two months of 2010, I can report to you that that looks a lot more promising.

Over to new markets. New markets increased by 5% to €0.9 million on a like-for-like basis, i.e. adjusted for the 2009 contract renegotiation in Italy and for the €50 million of profits, which is cast out to A2A also in Italy. New markets were actually up over 50%.

Climate and renewables benefited from higher installed capacity, 640 megawatts of higher capacity after year-end and 50% increase in output to now 8 terawatt hours for the full year. Those assets in the U.S. that we run on a merchant basis are still suffering from the low power price environments. Hence, they are still basically break even.

Russia has delivered a superb 2010. Hot weather and the pickup in industrial activity have improved spreads and volumes. Also middle of the year the liberalization rate increased from 60% to 80% and since the beginning of this year, we are at 100%. As Johannes has already commented upon, we expect a strong momentum in this business to continue also in 2011. The key driver though will now be the new plants that come on stream. In Italy, we have 2 of 4 mentioned effects that inflate the 2009 results.
Adjusted for those two effects together make up for €260 million, the Italian business is actually up by 8%. Spain continues to hold up against a fairly tough market environment.

Let me now move further down in the P&L, our net interest cost for 2010 would actually have been flat had we not incurred a one-time minus €126 million charge caused by the future prepayment into the renewable energy fund created by the German government. Our payment into this fund can be used as an offsetting amount post 2016. However, the time value of money disadvantage needs to be recorded today as an interest charge. Net bookings were again substantial in 2010 and added up to €2.9 billion. The main item this year was clearly the sale of the gap pressures. However, to remind you, we also had a gas permit tax in 2009 resulting from our swap into our stake in . In total the 2009 bookings were even higher mainly due to the disposal of generation capacity.

Other non-operating earnings were up €0.4 billion, here the biggest positive this year was to mark the markets of derivatives, which was €1.6 billion higher than last year. Clearly the big negative effect in 2010 was the asset and goodwill impairments for our assets in Italy, Spain and France that we reported about in Q3 of 2010.

Over to chart 20. The effective tax rate is down from 25% in 2009 to 22% for the full year 2010. This is related to the various effects in the non-operating results, mainly the tax-free disposal of gas comp. The tax charge on the operating result which leads to our adjusted net income has rather increased to roughly 26% which is closer to the our average guidance of 27% we have been getting. This is mainly due to less earnings from participations, which are already taxed, such as Thüga.

The result from discontinued operations include beyond U.S. Midwest, the 2009 result was burdened by the settlement cost for WKE, this reasonably unfavorable coal contract we had was in 2010 we rerecorded a roughly €900 million in common charge for that business in the context of the disposal. Minority interests are substantially up this year, better results in the German DSOs in our Russian power biz and some one-off effects in our Eastern European markets are the reasons for this.

Over to chart 21. You all are familiar with the reconciliation of adjusted net income. The reason why it is down slightly more than what we had expected i.e. we've always been telling you it's between minus 3% and plus 3% and now we're down minus 4%, is the €126 million interest charge that I spoke about earlier. We had not anticipated to sign a contract with the German government on future payments into a federal renewable energy fund in the format that was then created in the later stage of the year. Other than that, we are perfectly in line with our plan.

Let us now move on to the cash flow and indebtedness. Operating cash flow is nicely up by 24%, now clearly exceeding the €10 billion mark. Why is that? EBITDA is up by €400 million in addition, certain items of the 2009 EBITDA had no cash impact, such as the release in provision against the unfavorable power contract in Italy. The net effects of these non-cash items and EBITDA as such that we see another €0.2 billion increase in '10 versus 2009.

In PEG's Gas storage, we have a net investment largely price driven of €800 million, which was partly compensated by other positive working capital effects totaling €0.4 billion. In 2009, we had the MEGAL fine burdening our cash flow that was obviously not repeated in '10. The last loss position is tax related.
